docs.lead_paragraph: Previously, I was with a managed care practice and saw as many as eight patients an hour -- about six minutes a patient. Now I see about three patients in an hour. The other day a patient came in, 38 weeks pregnant. She said, ''I'm scared.'' It takes a lot longer than six minutes to respond to that. Pregnancy is a fragile time, especially a first pregnancy. Much of what I do is offer reassurance. Almost half of my obstetric patients are over 35, and there is a lot of concern. I've gotten telephone calls late at night. I'm a new father myself, and I understand the fears.

headline.main: Happy to Be Co-Pilot During Labor

docs.lead_paragraph: THE BEST A MAN CAN GET By John O'Farrell 260 pages. Broadway Books. $29.95 ''We've all done it,'' acknowledges Michael Adams, John O'Farrell's connubially challenged comic hero. ''We've all kept little secrets from our partners. We've all avoided telling them an awkward detail or subtly skirted over something we'd rather they didn't know. We've all rented a secret room on the other side of the city where we could hide half the week to get away from all the boring, exhausting baby stuff. Oh, that last one is just me apparently.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Hartford school administrators want to distribute contraceptives in the city's public schools to reduce high levels of teenage pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases. The administrators' proposal, which officials are calling less controversial than those of previous years, met with immediate criticism from a Roman Catholic schools official, who said it would confuse students.

headline.main: In Hartford Schools, a New Plan To Distribute Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Hartford, Conn, school administrators propose plan to distribute contraceptives in city's public schools to reduce teen pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases; superintendent of schools Anthony Amato says distribution will be based on parental consent and will be accompanied by increased education (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OVER the last century, theater has been on the front line in the effort to heal society's deepest traumas. But as yet it has found few ways of exorcising the genocidal horrors perpetrated by Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge on the people of Cambodia from 1975 to 1979. ''Continuum -- Beyond the Killing Fields,'' which will play at the New Theater on Chapel Street at Yale University from Wednesday through Saturday as part of the Festival of Arts and Ideas, aims to remedy this situation by bringing the creative process into the heart of the country's recent history. Devised by Ong Keng Sen, artistic director of Singapore's Theatreworks, and rehearsed within Cambodia's ancient Angkor temple complex, ''Continuum'' tells the chilling stories -- in spoken, sung and danced drama -- of how three classical dancers and a shadow puppeteer survived Khmer Rouge labor camps in Battambang Province. In October, the piece will go to Robertson Quay in Singapore and next year to Phnom Penh for performances expected to be held in Tuol Sleng, the regime's infamous detention and torture center, now a genocide museum.

headline.main: Making Dance of the Killing Fields

docs.abstract: Article by Robert Turnbull describes Continuum--Beyond the Killing Fields, spoken, sung and danced drama in which Cambodian artists tell story of how three classical dancers and shadow puppeteer survived Khmer Rouge labor camps in Cambodia; it will play at New Theater at Yale University as part of Festival of Arts and Ideas; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the last few years, women's magazines that focus primarily on health issues have multiplied faster than multiple-birth baby strollers on the Upper East Side. Where once there were two or three, now there is a health magazine for every stage of a woman's life, offering coverage of everything from the mommy track to menopause, from kundalini yoga to Kegel exercises, food allergies to folic acid.

headline.main: Looking for Health News? A Bikini Belly? There's More to Read

docs.lead_paragraph: That February night, Gary Langis was doing his usual thing. That is, he was delivering sterile hypodermic needles to two heroin addicts here, and picking up dirty needles to be sure they were disposed of safely. A former addict himself, whose wife died of AIDS she contracted from drug use, Mr. Langis said he felt compelled to make such deliveries often, working with an underground group of needle-exchange volunteers called the New England Prevention Alliance.

headline.main: Needle-Trading Programs Have Few Inroads in U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: The empty days on the isolated Standing Rock Reservation crawl along with the pace of lazy clouds, drifting in sync with a serene stretch of the bordering Missouri River. In the mood to speed this slow-drip existence along, Russell Archambault and his friends would pour gasoline into a milk jug, about a quarter of the way up, then put their mouths over the opening and inhale the fumes. Huffing gas, they called it. They were 12 years old and getting high.

headline.main: Fleeing Stereotype, Seeking Stardom; Sioux Took a Dream and Left the Reservation

docs.abstract: Russell Archambault, 24-year-old Lakota Sioux basketball player, discusses his struggle to escape dire social conditions into which he was born on reservation and overcome stereotypes about Indian athletes; interview; photos; he was dismissed from University of Minnesota team for violating rules, but is now at Huron University (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10. Now Playing ''THE ANIMAL.'' Starring Rob Schneider and Colleen Haskell. Directed by Luke Greenfield (PG-13, 83 minutes). The goofy new Rob Schneider comedy isn't the gross-out farce that its title suggests. The star portrays a meek, much-persecuted police department file clerk who, after being implanted with animal organs after a near-fatal car accident, fights against the instincts of the donor beasts that rise up inside him. Especially when he goes into a mating dance with a female goat and feeds a bird (bird style) in an animal shelter, this fable about the dog beneath the skin is very funny. Mr. Schneider brings an endearing innocence to a role that others would have played with a nasty leer (Stephen Holden).
